meanings.definition: A member of the clergy who conducts religious services.
meanings.sent1: The kind minister led the church service on Sunday.
meanings.sent2: The minister delivered a powerful sermon to the congregation.
meanings.sent3: The minister joked that even angels need a day off from singing.
meanings.sent4: Her words were like a minister of hope in the midst of despair.
meanings.sent5: The minister's voice echoed through the chapel, filling it with peace.

meanings.sent1: The prime minister addressed the nation on television.
meanings.sent2: The foreign minister met with diplomats from other countries.
meanings.sent3: The minister of finance accidentally wore mismatched socks to the meeting.
meanings.sent4: She was a minister of change, reshaping policies for the better.
meanings.sent5: The minister's decisions carried the weight of the entire government.

meanings.definition: To attend to the needs of someone or something.
meanings.sent1: She would minister to the injured animals at the shelter.
meanings.sent2: The nurse rushed to minister to the patient in pain.
meanings.sent3: He tried to minister to his friend's broken heart with kind words.
meanings.sent4: Her soothing voice seemed to minister to the troubled souls in the room.
meanings.sent5: The warm soup seemed to minister to his cold body after being out in the snow.

meanings.definition: To administer or dispense something, such as a sacrament or medication.
meanings.sent1: The doctor will minister the necessary medication to the patient.
meanings.sent2: She carefully ministered the sacrament to each member of the congregation.
meanings.sent3: The robot was programmed to minister the correct amount of oil to the machines.
meanings.sent4: Her hands seemed to minister healing to those she touched.
meanings.sent5: The rain seemed to minister life to the parched earth, bringing forth greenery.
